turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Come on, you! Before we slap you down.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Do you want us to call the cops and have them give you the boots?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Where is he, before we beat it out of you?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Come on, Pinky! Give 'em a little third degree.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Make them talk and you got Williams, Pinky!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Hold the phone!

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: I'll have it in a minute.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: I'll call.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Three sixes. Is that any good?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Goodbye, Yonson.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: So long, Hildy.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: What a chase!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: No luck on Williams, yet -- call you back.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: You ain't gettin' out o' here!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Now, where is he?

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: We know what you're up to.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Probably goin' out to get Williams.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: How's everything, Gus?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I can't complain.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh -- I'll take the same, I guess. And coffee.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Little rum in yours, too?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I guess so.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No -- just coffee, Gus.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Just coffee.  And you, sir?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry, Gus! My foot must have slipped.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: That's all right.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Gus, this --

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Good coffee, isn't it?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Same way you did.  Through that gate.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I gave strict orders that nobody was to interview Williams without my permission.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: All right, then, I'll just run the story that Sheriff Hartman is afraid to let reporters interview his prisoner. Of course, with election coming, that might do you a lot of harm, but just as you say.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Now, wait a minute! I'm not afraid of anything. What were you going to write about Williams?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, nothing much. Just that the state had proved he was sane -- and he admits it himself. If you don't want me to run it --

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Oh, that'll be all right, Hildy. Go ahead, run it. And you can say I treated him well, too.  'Lo, Earl. How are you feeling?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, thanks Sheriff. I'm leaving town tonight.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: You ought to stay over. You always wrote a good hanging story, Hildy.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's awful kind of you, Sheriff. I've got to get started on my interview. See you later.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Just a minute, Johnson!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Let go o' me. What's the idea?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Take your paws off me!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Hold her, boys!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Let me go!  Fellows, something's happened to my mother-in-law.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Hang onto her! Keep her in here!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I don't know anything, I tell you. There's been an accident.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Johnson, there's something very peculiar going on.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You can send somebody with me if you don't believe me!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I wasn't born yesterday. Now the boys tell me you and this Mollie Malloy --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Nobody's trying to put anything over on you. I'm getting out of here and you can't stop me!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Johnson, I'm going to the bottom of this. What do you know about Williams? Are you going to talk or aren't you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What do I know about Williams?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: All right, boys. Take her along. I got ways of making her talk.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Where'd you get this?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I've got a right to carry a gun if I want to.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Not this gun!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: He went over to the hospital to call on Professor Egelhoffer.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: With a bag of marshmallows.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: He's harmless.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Don't take any chances. Shoot through the desk.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: He can't hurt anybody. You've got his gun.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's murder!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: All right! Carl! Frank! One of you get on each side of the desk. Take hold of the cover.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: If the Mayor wants me, he knows where I am.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: This tear bomb went off unexpectedly in the hands of Sheriff Hartman's Bombing Squad.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: What went off?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Four of Mr. Hartman's Deputy Sheriffs were rushed to the hospital --

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: A fine fair-weather friend you are!

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: The names are Merwyn D. Mayor, who is the Mayor's brother-in-law --

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: After all I've done for you --

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Howard Shenken, the Sheriff's uncle on his mother's side --

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Where is he?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Where he used to live. You can catch the Riot Squad -- it's just going out.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I'm Sheriff Hartman. You want me?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: You're certainly a hard fellow to find, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: For who?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Earl Williams. The reprieve.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Read it! Insane, he says.  He knows very well that Williams ain't insane!

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Yeah. But I --

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Well, wait a minute, will you? I'm in conference.

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: No, I couldn't do that.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Just one second --

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: That's good, because my health ain't what it used to be.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Pete, I want to talk to you!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I ain't got time, Fred, honest. I'll see you after.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Did you actually give Williams that gun?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: The professor asked me for it -- I thought it was for something scientific!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Pete, I've got a mighty unpleasant task to perf --

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Now, listen, Fred. Just give me a few hours before you make any decisions. I'll get results. I'm doing everything humanly possible. I've just sworn in four hundred deputies.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Four hundred! Do you want to bankrupt this administration?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I'm getting them for twelve dollars a night.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Twelve dollars! -- For those rheumatic uncles of yours?  Out shooting everybody they see for the fun of it?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: If you're talking about my brother- in-law, he's worked for the city fifteen years.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Pete, you're through!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: What do you mean -- through?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: I mean I'm scratching your name off the ticket Tuesday and running Czernecki in your place. It's nothing personal. And, Pete -- it's the only way out. It's a sacrifice we all ought to be glad to make.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Fred!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Now, Pete! Please don't appeal to my Sentimental side.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Fred, I don't know what to say. A thing like this almost destroys a man's faith in human nature.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: I wish you wouldn't talk like that, Pete.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Our families, Fred. I've always looked on Bessie as my own sister.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: If there was any way out...

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: That gives you an idea of what I'm up against!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: We're up against a lot more than that with that nutty slogan you invented: 'Reform the Reds With a Rope'.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Williams ain't a Red, and you know it!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Well, there's a lot of Communistic sympathizers around --

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: I know it! But they've got nothing to do with this case! Do you realize there are two hundred thousand votes at stake and unless we hang Earl Williams we're going to lose 'em?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: But we're going to hang him, Fred. He can't get away.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: The Governor gave me his word of honor he wouldn't interfere. Two days ago!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: And you fell for it, Pete. It frightens me what I'd like to do to you.  Who else knows about this?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Pure politics!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: An attempt to ruin us!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Dementia praecox Oh-h-h!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: We got to think fast before those lying reporters get hold of this. What'll we tell 'em?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Tell 'em the party is through in this State on account of you.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Ah, Fred --  Hello... this is Hartman --

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: And you can tell 'em as an afterthought that I want your resignation now!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Sssh. Wait, Fred.  What?... Where?... Where? Holy Moses!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: They got him!  Wait a minute -- hold the wire.  They got Earl Williams surrounded -- the Riot Squad has -- in his house.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Tell 'em to hold the wire.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I did.  Hold the wire.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Cover up that transmitter!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: No -- don't out me off.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: How would you like to have a job for three hundred and fifty dollars a month. That's almost a hundred dollars a week!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Hold your horses -- will you, Olsen? Hurry up, Fred!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Now what do you say?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: We'll fix that, too.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Just -- one -- second!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: All right. Tell 'em to shoot to kill.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Shoot to kill, I said.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I don't know, Fred. There's that reprieve if they ever find out.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Nobody reprieved that policeman he murdered. Now, do as I tell you.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Hello, Olsen... Listen...  Shoot to kill... That's the orders pass the word along... No! We dont want him! And listen, Olsen, five- hundred bucks for the guy that does the job... Yes, I'll be right out there.  Well, I hope that's the right thing to do.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Now take that guilty look off your face, Pete -- and stop trembling like a horse.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: If we didn't have election Tuesday I'd have this on my conscience.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Fine work, Pete! You certainly delivered the goods. I'm proud of you.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Look kind o' natural, don't they, Fred?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: A sight for sore eyes!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Aiding an escaped criminal! And a little charge of kidnapping I'm looking into.  But that's the jail! There must be somebody there!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Well! Looks like about ten years apiece for you birds!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Who is this man?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Throw him out, Frank.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: You drunken idiot! Arrest him! The idea of coming here with a cock-and- bull story like that!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: It's a frame-up! Some imposter!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: That's a lie!!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: I never saw him before!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Take those handcuffs off our friends, Pete. That wasn't at all necessary.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I was just going to!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Walter, I can't tell you how badly I feel about this. There was no excuse for Hartwell to fly off the handle.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I was only doing my duty. Nothing personal in it.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: And so do I!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: So do you what, you hoodoo!  And now, Mr. Pinkus, if you'll come with us, we'll take you over to the Warden's office and deliver this reprieve.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Fine, thanks, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: That's good, Earl. Oh, they've got another alienist to see you. He ought to be here any minute. Don't go to sleep, will you?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: I won't.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Hildy, how'd you like a couple of tickets for the hanging?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: I hope you're pretty nearly through with me, Doctor, I'm getting a little fatigued.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Yeah, you don't want to tire him out, Doctor.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Got you, Williams!

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Go on -- shoot me!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Let him out of here, Lieutenant.

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of stealing a watch. And they found the watch on him.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: And who accused him? Diamond Louis! One of the worst crooks in town! Why don't you arrest Louis instead of innocent people that he frames?

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: Now, Hildy --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let him out?

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: All right. You can't. But tomorrow the Post will run the story of that roulette game on 43rd Street that your brother-in-law runs. And we'll print that you get five hundred a month for forgetting about it!

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: Now, Hildy, don't be hasty! I can't let him out.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You can let him out on bail, can't you?

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: Five hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You'll take fifty and like it!

turns.speaker: LIEUTENANT
turns.text: Well, all right. But I'm liable to get into a jam.

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: Oh, I ain't doing that any more. I'm retired. I'm one of you fellas now -- a newspaper man.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Editorials?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Wait a minute, Walter. You can't do that!

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: My name is Louis Peluso.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Where's the old lady?

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: I'm telling you!

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: We run smack into a police patrol. You know what I mean? We broke it in half!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh-h-h... was she hurt?

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: I'm telling you. Can you imagine bumping into a load of cops?! They come rollin' out like oranges!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What did you do with her?

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: Search me! When I come to I was running down Thirty-fifth Street.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: -- You were with her. You were in the cab, weren't you?

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: Was I? The driver got knocked cold.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Nobody's going to rush me into anything!  You keep away from me!

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: All right, Judge.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Gentlemen of the Press! Always picking on somebody who can't defend himself -- the littler the better.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Phone for you, Hildy.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Oh, some insurance man. Are you in?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Give me that!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: There goes another scrub lady.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I'll go right after it.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, anyhow, I won't be covering stuff like this any more.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: What's the matter? Getting yellow?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: It's getting so a girl can't step out of the room without being discussed by a bunch of old ladies.  Hello, Post... Mr. Walter Burns, please.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Well, Hildy, we were only saying that a swell reporter like you wouldn't give this up so easily.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: This is Hildy Johnson...  Oh, I can give it up all right. Without a single quiver. I'm going to live like a human being -- not like you rats.  Oh, is that you, Walter dear? Oh, I didn't mean "dear." That was just habit, I guess. Oh, be yourself, Walter. I've got some news for you... Yes, I got the interview, but I've got some news that's more important.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Burns. Yes, she's still here.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'll take it.  What's the matter, Mr. Burns -- don't you understand English? -- Why, your language is shocking, Mr. Burns -- positively shocking! I don't mind because I was married to you and know what to expect, but suppose Central is listening in... Oh, did you hear that, Central? We ought to report him, don't you think?... Oh, fooey on you!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Any news?

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: Yeah. I was never so tired in my life.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: You fight it cut.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: And up a dime.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I don't know why you boys are so good to me.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Your poker's improved a lot, Hildy. Lend me two bucks, will you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Nothing doing. I'm playing for keeps.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Certified, eh? Who is it -- your milkman?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: But, Bruce, don't keep it in your wallet!... Well, you see --  -- there's an old newspaper superstition that the first big check you get you -- you put in the lining of your hat. That brings you good luck for ten years.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Say, I've been a reporter twenty years and never heard any hooey like that. Where'd you get it?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I made it up just now, and who's asking you?  I know it's silly, honey, but do it for me, won't you?... Yes, right now.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Hello, Hildy. I thought you were gone.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I thought so, too.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Did you get that, Hildy?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No -- what?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: If Walter Burns calls, hold the wire for me, will you? I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Okay, Hildy.  Well, we can't get any official statement --

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Okay.  Forget it.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What's the matter with you boys? Afraid it might rain? If you want to go, I'll cover this end.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Look out, you --

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: What's the use of fighting, Hildy?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Have you got my dough?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Oh, sure. The boss sent me over with it. Four hundred dollars, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Four hundred and fifty and I'll cut your throat if you try any tricks!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: All right, all right. You can't blame a guy for tryin', can you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Come on with that money!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: First you got to sign a receipt.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Where's the money?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Keep your shirt on. I got it -- right here.  One hundred -- two hundred -- three hundred -- four hundred -- and fifty. Now sign.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Here!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Thanks. So long, Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: So long, nothing! Where's Bruce Baldwin's wallet?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: None of that innocent stuff, you double-crossing hyena! You stuck Bruce Baldwin in jail this afternoon on a phony charge that he swiped your watch, and you frisked his wallet! Now, give me that wallet or I'll stick you in jail and it won't be on any phony charge either! It'll be for life!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Now don't get excited, Hildy! I don't know what you're talking about -- but is this Mr. Baldwin's wallet?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You know it is!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I didn't frisk him. He must have dropped it in Burns' office. I didn't know whose it was.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No -- and you don't know that your cheap boss has had Mr. Baldwin arrested again -- do you?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What -- already? Why, the dame left only a minute before I did!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Kings and sixes.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: 'Kings and sixes The pot affixes'... Poetry. I learned that at my grandma's knee.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Any dope yet on how he got out?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: From all I can get the Sheriff let him out so's he could vote for him.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Hildy, I thought you were gone --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well -- I was going, but Mollie fainted away and I thought I ought to do what I could.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Some Hallowe'en goin' on outside. The whole police force standing on it's ear.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Hiding him where?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Mother!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Mother!

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: Don't you mother me! Playing cat-and- mouse with my poor boy! Keeping him looked up -- making us miss two trains -- and supposed to be married tomorrow!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Mother, I can explain everything. I'll go with you in five minutes and --

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: You don't have to go with me at all! Just give me my son's money and you can stay here forever as far as I'm concerned. Stay with that murderer you caught!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I don't know what she's talking about. I never said any such thing.

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: I'm quoting my son, and he has never lied to me.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Mother!

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: That man there!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Mother! Oh, I'm so glad to see you! Are you all right? Tell me.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: I couldn't plead insanity, because you see I'm just as sane as anybody else.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You didn't mean to kill that policeman?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Of course not. I couldn't kill anybody -- it's against everything I've ever stood for. They know it was an accident. They're not hanging me for that -- they're hanging me for my beliefs.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What are your beliefs, Earl?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: They're very simple. I believe in the Golden Rule. I'm not the first man to die for preaching it. But if they would only listen to it -- we could have a fine, decent world instead of this mass of hate that makes man do such cruel things.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: How would you go about applying the Golden Rule, Earl?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: I'd do away with the profit system and have production for use only. There's enough food and clothing and shelter for everybody if we'd use some sense.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: "Production for use only." Well, maybe that's the answer.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: It's the only answer. Everything has a use and if we let it be used for its purpose, we could solve all our problems. Food was meant to be eaten, not stored away in restaurants while poor people starved; clothing was meant to be worn, not piled up in stores while people went naked. Doesn't that make sense?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yes, that makes a lot of sense, Earl.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: A gun?  Why -- to shoot, of course.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Is that how you came to shoot the policeman?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Sure. You see, I'd never had a gun in my hand before and I didn't know what to do with it. Well, when I get stuck, I know that there's an answer for everything in production for use. So it came to me in a flash: what's a gun for? To shoot! So I shot. Simple isn't it?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Very simple, Earl.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: There's nothing crazy about that, is there?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, Earl, not at all.  Who sent you the flowers, Earl?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Miss Mollie Malloy. She's a wonderful person.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Isn't that her picture?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Yes. Isn't she beautiful?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Don't forget about production for use.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I won't, Earl.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: You're not going to phone anybody where I am.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Put down that gun, Earl.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You're not going to shoot me, Earl. I'm your friend, remember? I've got to write that story about your "Production for Use".

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Yes -- that's right. Production for use.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Earl, you don't want to hurt your friends, do you?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Don't move!

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Maybe you're my friend and maybe you're not -- but don't come any nearer. You can't trust anybody in this crazy world. Say, I'll bet I could shoot you from here.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Sure you could, Earl -- but you wouldn't want to do that, would you? You wouldn't want to kill anybody.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: No, no, you're right. I don't want to kill anybody. All I want to do is be let alone.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Earl, there's just one thing I ought to clear up for the interview.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: What's that? Only -- you're getting too near. I don't trust anybody.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I don't blame you, Earl.  If I were in your place I wouldn't trust anybody, either.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Keep away!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Earl, you must never do that again.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Oh, I'm awful tired. I couldn't go through another day like this.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, maybe you think I could!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Don't talk too loud.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Wakin' me up in the middle of the night -- talkin' to me about things they don't understand. Callin' me a Bolshevik. I'm an anarchist. It's got nothin' to do with bombs. It's the philosophy that guarantees every man freedom. You see that, don't you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Sure I do, Earl.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Quiet, Mollie, quiet!

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Don't cry, Mollie, there's nothing to cry about.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: How'd you get here, Earl?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Down the drainpipe. I didn't mean to shoot him. You believe me, don't you, Mollie?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Stop screaming, Mollie or we're sunk. I'm trying to think of something before those reporters get back.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Let 'em take me. It's better that way.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: What good'll it do?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: We'll get you out in ten minutes.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Come on, Mollie. This is no place for you.

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: They're not human!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: They're newspaper men, Mollie. They can't help themselves. The Lord made them that way.

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: It wasn't the Lord! It was the devil!

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: Where are they gone? You know where they are?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Wait a minute, Mollie.

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: They got him surrounded some place -- gonna shoot him like a dog!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Mollie, they haven't got him. You gotta help me, Mollie! We've got to do something!

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Quiet, Mollie!

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: There's somethin' funny going on around here.
